author: {'steamid': '76561198159557537', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 290, 'last_played': 1697425373}
review:
I feel as if a review of a VR game that requires activity should include a basic description of the writer's health: I am a mildly obese 30-ish year old man. I'm not particularly fit, but I don't have any serious disabilities. Unless your fitness is extremely poor, I believe that fitness is not likely a barrier for playing this game.

Nightstar: Starfighter is a somewhat standard shmup in VR form. You have a ship, which binds to one of your controllers (left by default, more on that later). You can put up a temporary shield, which keeps you from being hurt, and you can turn on autofire. You can pick up powerups - each level of power increases your shot power, score multiplier, and the difficulty of enemies that come at you. This caps out at 20. If you get hit, you lose a lot of your power.

There's a relatively low number of different enemy types, and they all more or less shoot directly at you. This makes the bullet patterns not particularly fresh, and someone who has played a good number of shmups will have no real problem figuring out how to stream the bullets.

The color scheme is appropriate for this game - the bullets are a bright green, which makes them easy to spot on the black background. Enemies are reasonable to look at - they are neither extremely ugly or extremely detailed.

There is a slight lack of polish in the lack of options - there is no built-in way to swap which hand the ship is bound to. There is a way to work around this - by turning off the left controller before starting up your VR headset - but it shows a lack of effort on the developer's part.

The music is fine if you are playing the game for less than 20 minutes. I comment on the other case later.

As the current top of the leaderboard, I must comment on the scoring. The fact that your temporary shield is given to you generously makes it not particularly easy to get hit. Moreover, the fact that health pickups are relatively abundant (they are not *very* abundant, but they are available enough that one can pick them up reliably) means that the game is very forgiving. Last, the power cap at 20 makes score gain linear, and the difficulty does not increase past a certain point. The point at which difficulty stops increasing is somewhat low. This turns scorechasing into an endurance test, which is deeply unsatisfying for anyone who has the ability to crack the top 25. Moreover, the music starts to become boring after about 20 or 30 minutes. A lack of enemy variety also makes the game quite boring. Last, defeating the boss is deeply unsatisfying - the point value is low compared to the enemy carriers, and even though it drops 3 powerups, the powerups drop far away enough that they never reach the player. I acknowledge that this is only a problem for an extreme minority of the people who play this game, but I must point it out regardless.

For someone new-ish to the genre who has a VR headset, and who is looking for something to play for 15 or 20 minutes while they warm up, this is probably a reasonable buy at sale prices (and this game does go on sale enough for this to be a factor). The amount of calories you are likely to burn playing this game is fair. You should expect to be moving somewhat constantly while playing the game. This game is quite good for those without experience in this genre who want to play it in VR, and for them I suggest considering this game at sale prices.

For someone who is experienced at playing shmups, I strongly advise skipping this game. It will grow boring fast, and you will grow bored and sloppy.

review:
[b][u]I played this on the Oculus Rift with Touch controllers and it works fine [/u][/b].  Other than it has the same issue as the HTC Vive which is you have to use your left hand controller. You have to make precise movements to shoot objects at a distance, making the slightest adjustment.

I played this game for 30 minutes and never got past the first level.  That had a lot to do with being right hand dominant, but also this game is challenging.  Despite the frustration of being close to 100% several times, I had a lot of fun and enjoyed the challenge.  However, it did seem like some run through's success was based on random powerups.  Sometimes I quickly got a pair of squadron teammates to help me out, and other times I had none.  

There's this one ship that one shot kills you.  I didn't realize that until like the 10th time I died which one it was.  I think I can definitely get past the first level, with some luck.  I definitely think this one is a lot better than the Lab.  It's quite the deal on sale price of $1.99  USD.

review:
At the moment this game has only positive reviews, so I'm gonna add some negatives before I apply for my refund.

- The 8 levels aren't all that different from each other
- There seems to be only one boss with two stages
- It's too easy. I got to top 50 on my third attempt. Of course my leaderboard position doesn't affect my enjoyment, but for 5-10 minutes while playing with plenty of powerups and killing the boss over and over I felt like nothing was changing and I wasn't being challenged.
- Felt like the game required me to raise my controller above my head to best avoid getting hit. This made my shoulder hurt.
- It's fairly hard to aim

In conclusion: Get it on sale and see if you like it more than I did.

review: Nightstar is very much like The Lab's Xortex, but different in enough ways as to merit being a seperate game.  That said, if you like Xortex, you'll certainly like Nightstar. It is very much the standard, controller becomes spaceship, shooter game but it adds powerups, wingmen, and even objectives (protect fleeing spaceships) to the mix. While one can say it is repetive, etc... having grown up on Galaga and classic games ike that, I get that a good game does not have to be deep or long in content to be enjoyable. Sometimes simply being a shooter game can be good. Thankfully the developer has added constant firing as an option to save your controller from the beating it would take otherwise. Overall, this is one Vive game that I find myself going into for a quick game often. It is also one I use to demo the Vive to people with since it is so straight forward and reminds one of old school arcade games. Therefore I highly recommend it to everyone as a VR library addition.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066003923', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 806, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 418, 'last_played': 1548129597}
review:
I've been having a BLAST with this game.  Dev has been very attentive and engaging over Reddit.  So far this is one of my favorite VR games.  It's pretty basic arcade gameplay.  No intricate upgrade systems or any fancy attempts to add rougelike elements. 

Just straight up FUN ass gameplay.  For anyone who played with toy spaceships as a kid who wants to actually fly one around in space shooting bad guys, THIS is the game to pick up!

I've heard it compared to a couple other titles, but personally haven't found anything that hit the spot like this game.  

It's a unique design that doesn't try too hard to be different.  Great sound and music, and very satisfying imagry with plenty of explosions in space.  I expected to like this game after playing the demo, but I didn't expect to enjoy it THIS much.   I grew up loving everything about the space/sci-fi genera and always imagined I'd need to be flying first person, in the cockpit to get this much enjoyment out of a space shooter, but the truth is I like this better than any other space shooters in VR that I've played so far.   

What's even cooler is you can download a demo to try it out for yourself before buying.  I personally payed $14.99 for it durring Steams Winter sale, and I'll be completely honest I don't even regret paying more than the current price.  One reason for that is that one of my motion controllers was broken for about a week and a half so having a game I could play with one controller saved me a ton of grief for those 9 days (felt like a couple months) before deciding I could just fix the thing myself.  

That's all beside the point.  Try the demo, if you like it even a little it's definitly worth the current price for the amount of enjoyment you'll get from it.  Not to mention it's decent workout dodging all that incoming fire.  Just keep your chaperone on or you'll be tempted to chase a powerup through a wall.

review:
Yep, this is a keeper.  Tried the demo, bought the full game after two plays.  This is completely different than any other VR game I've played so far, in that it isn't really first person.  It's more third person, with one controller being the ship.  It moves wherever you move the controller, pretty much instantly.  It's really easy to just stand in one spot and just wave the controller around, but this is a room scale game.  Walk around to get better angles, or dodge thick packs of things that are coming from one area, etc.  Awesome game, lots of replayability.

My one complaint would be how long it takes to reset after game over.  I want to click through whatever scoring it's showing me and just restart immediately, but it makes me wait ~20 seconds and then brings the menu up to allow a new game.

review:
别人推荐的这款游戏，三天就玩了4个多小时，而且还冲到了排行榜首。
　　优点是沉浸感很好，操作也比较方便，玩这个游戏基本上就不能站在一个地方不动，必须不停的移动身体和手柄（因为战舰就在手柄上），玩这个做有氧运动也是可以的，可以连续做战一小时以上。
　　说下我遇到的问题：相同的问题出现过好几次，就是玩到中途会莫名奇妙的报错，然后就只有用鼠标点击错误报告，我今天刚玩的这次也是，我已经玩到二十几万分了，本来想再次刷新一下之前的纪录，结果就突然报错，什么也没有记录。这种中途报错不知道是什么原因，难道是软件以为我是开了挂，不会吧。希望开发方能修复这种错误，这种报错是非常影响心情的。
　　再说对游戏的看法：目前的兵种就那么几种，场景也基本上是重复的，打了一个boss后面出现的也是一样的boss,是个无限循环，希望后续增加新的兵种、武器和新的场景。

review:
Super fun game! The feeling of traveling through space is awesome, and because of the static background and steady velocity, works well without any dizziness whatsoever. The difficulty is perfectly balanced between too easy and too hard, making it very satisfying to actually get to the next level. The intensity of the game seems to pick up as you get upgrades, so it's always a challenge to keep your ship in top shape (you lose some upgrades when you're shot). The game works well for any-heighted people (even kids!).

There are a few annoying things that will probably get cleaned up in time by the developer. For instance, there's no way to exit the game except from within the VR headset (you lose mouse control once the game goes full screen and takes over the monitor). I look forward to seeing further updates!

author: {'steamid': '76561197971127571', 'num_games_owned': 747, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 52, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1471940242}
review:
Here is my very first impression review on nightstar after I got the key from the developer. It is a shoot’em up game like r-type or the lab minigame Xortex. While Xortex is a more static room scale experience, nightstar feels like a scroller game. Best description is here a front-scroller because all the enemy ships and asteroids fly towards you. 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
It’s a shoot’em up, simple target the enemy, press the trigger and try not got hit. The ship got a moment of inertia so you have to calculate this. The only down side is enemies shooting even they passed you, this makes some very unfair attacks from the blind spot. 
Also some of the little fragments look like the filling stars that pass you, so you run into them and taking random damage. 
Also the spaceship shoots a bit upwards can’t tell if bug or feature.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=34Ocr3Xpwb4

[h1]Graphic[/h1]
It looks very good for an early access game. The little ships looks very distinctive even on low quality. Effects like explosions and the red fade out during dead rounds the geme.

[h1]Sounds[/h1]
Awesome. The Soundtrack and the sound effects are very good and let the game feels like an old arcade game.

[h1]VR compatibility[/h1]
Even the constant “scrolling” did, at least for me, not any nausea. The ground grid is for my taste a bit far away, but makes a nice grounding in space. The game can be played with one controller so you can switch hands during play to avoid a tennis elbow. Or play the game while a controller is broken or on repair. It’s a plus point.

[h1]Result[/h1]
Can’t wait to see how the future of the game looks like more power ups or different ships.

review:
I bought this based off a review saying this was Xortex 2.0.  That being said it is nothing like Xortex.. it is a different style of game.  Nightstar is a scrolling shooter, Xortex is a room scale shooter. 

That being said this is a fun arcade game that I plan on playing a lot more.  

As I play more I find my ship getting hit by dimly lit objects that are very difficult to see..  Hopefully in the future this gets updated.

I give this a positive review because it is worth a play if you buy a lot of games.  I rarely purchase games... If I had the chance to demo this game before buying I would have spent my money on a different game.
